text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This is a complete revision of IRM 13.2.1, Systemic Advocacy Overview. It has been totally restructured based on the reorganization of Systemic Advocacy (SA) and related business units program name changes. The title has changed from Processing Advocacy Issues to Systemic Advocacy Overview and all sections renumbered.

Primarily Taxpayer Advocate Service and all Operating Divisions and functions.
Table of Contents
Overview

) Throughout the Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS), employees play a vital in addressing taxpayers’ speciﬁc issues. These taxpayer problems come to TAS’s attention through several sources including offices within TAS, Revenue Service (IRS) employees, taxpayers, practitioners, and other stakeholders. (
) This section provides information about Systemic Advocacy (SA) and its functions and responsibilities within TAS. and (

) The section details the responsibilities of the Executive Director, Systemic Advocacy (EDSA), Deputy to the Executive Director, Systemic Advocacy, Technical Advocacy (DEDSA-TA), Deputy to Executive Director, Systemic Advocacy, Proactive Advocacy (DEDSA-PA) and the work of their staffs, their relationships within and outside the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). (

) This section provides guidance to the IRS and TAS employees about how fulﬁll their responsibilities in the advocacy process. It also describes the following: • The NTA’s Annual Report to Congress (ARC); • The Integrating Advocacy initiative; • The Taxpayer Advocate Directive (TAD); • The Taxpayer Rights Impact Statement (TRIS), and; • The processes associated with identifying, submitting, reviewing, assigning, developing, and resolving advocacy issues. (
) The evolution of TAS began with the establishment of the Problem Program (PRP) in

PRP was designed to handle taxpayer problems could not be settled through normal IRS channels. Originally the limited its advocacy role, protecting taxpayers’ rights only on a basis. TAS has broadened the depth and scope of the advocacy mission, placing a new emphasis on protecting taxpayer rights at all levels, within IRS operating divisions and functions. (
) The
Taxpayer Bill of Rights II (TBOR
) required the IRS to ensure designated functional officials respond to the NTA’s recommendations for improving IRS performance and preventing problems. (
) The IRS Restructuring and Reform Act of
(RRA
) brought changes to TAS. Among the most signiﬁcant was the development of SA its elevation to a level equal with Case Advocacy (CA). For additional tion, see IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures, Legislative and Organizational Structure. (

) During the past several years, both TAS and the IRS have developed a awareness of the need to focus on the root causes of problems as well as resolving individual cases. TAS has worked diligently to pinpoint and systemic deﬁciencies that may contribute to problems experienced by all taxpayers. (
) The NTA carries out his or her mission through ﬁve major program (
) Internal Revenue Manual
This section provides guidance to the IRS and TAS employees about how to fulﬁll their responsibilities in the advocacy process. It also describes the

The NTA’s Annual Report to Congress (ARC); The Integrating Advocacy initiative; The Taxpayer Advocate Directive (TAD); The Taxpayer Rights Impact Statement (TRIS), and; The processes associated with identifying, submitting, reviewing, assigning, developing, and resolving advocacy issues.

• The Taxpayer Advocate Directive (TAD); • The Taxpayer Rights Impact Statement (TRIS), and; • The processes associated with identifying, submitting, reviewing, assigning, developing, and resolving advocacy issues. The evolution of TAS began with the establishment of the Problem Program (PRP) in

PRP was designed to handle taxpayer problems could not be settled through normal IRS channels. Originally the limited its advocacy role, protecting taxpayers’ rights only on a basis. TAS has broadened the depth and scope of the advocacy mission, placing a new emphasis on protecting taxpayer rights at all levels, within all IRS operating divisions and functions. The
Taxpayer Bill of Rights II (TBOR
) required the IRS to ensure designated functional officials respond to the NTA’s recommendations for improving IRS performance and preventing problems. The IRS Restructuring and Reform Act of
(RRA
) brought sweeping changes to TAS. Among the most signiﬁcant was the development of SA its elevation to a level equal with Case Advocacy (CA). For additional tion, see IRM

, Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures, Legislative and Organizational Structure. During the past several years, both TAS and the IRS have developed a awareness of the need to focus on the root causes of problems as well as resolving individual cases. TAS has worked diligently to pinpoint and correct systemic deﬁciencies that may contribute to problems experienced by all taxpayers. The NTA carries out his or her mission through ﬁve major program
The NTA carries out his or her mission through ﬁve major program objectives:

Systemic • Administering the TAS (advocacy through taxpayer cases); • Identifying and addressing systemic and procedural problems by analyzing their underlying causes and recommending corrective (advocacy through analysis and administrative recommendations); • Identifying and addressing operational issues that affect taxpayers (advocacy through working immediate interventions); • Advocating taxpayers’ interests in the submission of legislative mendations; and • Advocating taxpayers’ interests through recommending changes to published guidance (Treasury and Counsel published guidance). (

) Advocacy thus falls into ﬁve general categories: • Resolving cases of economic burden or systemic burden on taxpayers; • Developing projects that identify and address systemic and problems and recommend solutions; • Addressing immediate interventions to respond expeditiously to tional issues affecting taxpayers • Proposing legislative recommendations to improve tax administration and reduce taxpayer burden; and • Recommending changes to published guidance to improve tion and reduce taxpayer burden for possible inclusion in the Office of the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (National Taxpayer Advocate Program) published guidance plan. (
) TAS is organized around two functions: • Case Advocacy; and • Systemic Advocacy (

) SA is not solely responsible for the identiﬁcation of systemic issues. Employees throughout TAS and the IRS regularly uncover problems that additional burden or expense to bear on taxpayers. TAS also draws on vations and suggestions from taxpayers, practitioners, and professional organizations in its effort to improve tax law and administration. (

) The advocacy role of TAS is apparent in its mission statement: “As an inde- pendent organization with the IRS, TAS assists taxpayers in resolving tax problems with the IRS, identiﬁes areas in which taxpayers have problems the IRS, and makes administrative and legislative recommendations to systemic tax issues.” (

) EDSA, DEDSA-TA, DEDSA-PA • The EDSA and DEDSA support the TAS mission by providing and oversight of the SA organization. As a direct report to the NTA, EDSA has responsibility for TAS programs that address systemic problems within the IRS. • There are two DEDSA’s of SA. The DEDSA-PA has responsibility for ARC, IMD/SPOC, and Systemic Advocacy Management System (SAMS) Programs. The DEDSA-TA oversees the SA technical groups (Processing, Examination, and Collection) who work on the annual reports, projects, and other collaborative efforts to resolve systemic issues • For a listing of the units and staff in the SA, see the TAS Directory. Administering the TAS (advocacy through taxpayer cases); Identifying and addressing systemic and procedural problems by analyzing their underlying causes and recommending corrective action (advocacy through analysis and administrative recommendations); Identifying and addressing operational issues that affect taxpayers (advocacy through working immediate interventions); Advocating taxpayers’ interests in the submission of legislative recom
mendations; and Advocating taxpayers’ interests through recommending changes to published guidance (Treasury and Counsel published guidance).
Advocacy thus falls into ﬁve general categories:

Resolving cases of economic burden or systemic burden on individual taxpayers; Developing projects that identify and address systemic and procedural problems and recommend solutions; Addressing immediate interventions to respond expeditiously to opera
tional issues affecting taxpayers Proposing legislative recommendations to improve tax administration and reduce taxpayer burden; and Recommending changes to published guidance to improve administra
tion and reduce taxpayer burden for possible inclusion in the Office of the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (National Taxpayer Advocate Program) published guidance plan.

The EDSA and DEDSA support the TAS mission by providing and oversight of the SA organization. As a direct report to the NTA, the EDSA has responsibility for TAS programs that address systemic problems within the IRS. There are two DEDSA’s of SA. The DEDSA
PA has responsibility for ARC, IMD/SPOC, and Systemic Advocacy Management System (SAMS) Programs. The DEDSA

TA oversees the SA technical groups (Processing, Examination, and Collection) who work on the annual reports, projects, and other collaborative efforts to resolve systemic issues For a listing of the units and staff in the SA, see the TAS Directory.

) The advocacy roles and responsibilities of the EDSA‘s staff include: a. Senior Technical Liaison(s) (STL). The NTA may identify areas of tax administration needing dedicated attention, and will name a STL to serve as the subject matter expert. STL’s serve as key advisors to the DNTA, and EDSA. They represent TAS on task forces and teams with the IRS and work with external holders to identify systemic issues. b. The topic areas may change at the discretion of the NTA. SA has ﬁve key issue areas which are each headed by a STL: Examination;Collection;Campus;Taxpaye
ervice; and Revenue Protection (
) ARC Program Managers IRC §
)(B)(i) requires the NTA to submit an annual report to Congress to identify the

most serious problems encountered by taxpayers and to make administrative and legislative recommendations to mitigate those problems. The ARC program managers oversee the Annual Report process and track the responses of the IRS to the recommendations contained within the ARC. The annual Objectives Report to Congress (known as the June Report to Congress (JRC)) is required by IRC §
)(B)(i). It is also co- ordinated by the ARC program managers. For a detailed discussion of the ARC and JRC processes, see IRM
, NTA’s ARC to Congress. (

) Systemic Issue Review and Evaluation Program (SIRE) The SIRE program identiﬁes the potential systemic issues in need of SA inter- vention by reviewing submissions on SAMS to identify existing and emerging issues that affect taxpayer rights, cause taxpayer burden, or are systemic in nature. SA accomplishes this by applying established review criteria, talking to submitters, thoroughly researching the submissions, determining prior TAS in- volvement, and recommending next steps. SAMS allows all TAS and IRS employees, as well as anyone outside of the IRS to submit a potential systemic issue to TAS. For additional information about SAMS processes see IRM
, SAMS Administration. . (
) Internal Management Documents/Single Point of Contact Program (IMD/ SPOC)Th

MD/SPOC program supports the SA mission by ensuring TAS reviews official communications that either designate authorities or provide guidance and instructions to IRS staff. The purpose of the review is to identify and recommend changes to procedures that unduly burden taxpayers or infringe upon taxpayer rights. TAS also uses the reviews to provide input to the clarity, accuracy, and effectiveness of IRMs, policy statements, delegations orders, letters, notices, forms, and publications. Members of the IMD/SPOC program serve on IMD-related councils, committees, groups, and task forces (e.g., IMD Council). They coordinate IRM drafting and publishing guidance with TAS IRM authors, reviewers, responsible managers, and directors. Staff also works with the Office of Taxpayer Correspondence (OTC) and Tax Forms and (TF) to facilitate feedback from TAS to the authors of letters, notices, forms, and publications. See IRM
, Internal Management Documents System, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Internal Management Document Program, for more information on the IMD/SPOC process. Internal Revenue Manual

a. Senior Technical Liaison(s) (STL). The NTA may identify areas of tax administration needing dedicated attention, and will name a STL to serve as the subject matter expert. STL’s serve as key advisors to the DNTA, and EDSA. They represent TAS on task forces and teams with the IRS and work with external holders to identify systemic issues. b. The topic areas may change at the discretion of the NTA. SA has ﬁve key issue areas which are each headed by a STL: Examination;Collection;Campus;Taxpaye
ervice; and Revenue Protection

IRC § 7803(c)(2)(B)(i) requires the NTA to submit an annual report to Congress to identify the 10 most serious problems encountered by taxpayers and to make administrative and legislative recommendations to mitigate problems. The ARC program managers oversee the Annual Report process and track the responses of the IRS to the recommendations contained within the ARC. The annual Objectives Report to Congress (known as the June Report to Congress (JRC)) is required by IRC § 7803(c)(2)(B)(i). It is also co- ordinated by the ARC program managers. For a detailed discussion of the ARC and JRC processes, see IRM 13.2.8, NTA’s ARC to Congress.
Systemic (

) Advocacy Efforts (AE) The AE Staff provides program and administrative guidance and support to EDSA. Current areas of responsibility include; The SA Quality Review Program, The SA Operational Review Coordination, SAMS Level Three Review Team, and support for the TAS Orientation Program for Leaders. AE Staff coordinates the revisions to the SA IRMs or project work and organizes the submission of data from SA program leaders for the Trends Analysis Report (STAR). The staff is involved in tracking ARC and recommendations and outcomes. (

) Technical Advocacy Groups There are three technical groups within SA: Processing, Examination, and lection. The staff of these groups are made up of analysts and technical advisors who work in a collaborated effort to resolve systemic problems. staff advocates work on systemic issues through a variety of approaches may include advocacy projects, IMD reviews, task forces, and the ARC. staff may recommend changes to: • Administrative procedures; • Published guidance; or • Legislation (
) Program Reports: Shar

oint™ (SP) and Business Objects Enterprise generate a variety of reports used to monitor the inventory, work status of Management SAMS Issues, Advocacy Projects (AP), Immediate Interventions (II), tion Gathering Projects (IGP), Collaborative Teams, Task Forces and IMD Reviews. (
) Program Effectiveness: SP and BOE are used to help identify open and project progression, and issues being addressed. (
) BOE is a data analysis system. Reports are created and accessed by personnel. Reports can only be deleted by a designated administrator. Controls (
) Shar
oint™ is a web-based collaborative platform that is a document agement and storage system. (

) This IRM uses several related terms to describe the advocacy process and procedures: a. Advocacy Issue -- The underlying systemic problem or issue that creates disservice, inequity, or otherwise adds to taxpayer burden. Systemic advocacy issues affect signiﬁcant numbers of taxpayers are rooted in laws, policies or procedures that are ﬂawed in design or implementation. b. Advocacy Issue or Submission -- An idea, suggestion, or reported problem that will advocate for the taxpayer by improving current tion, taxpayer equity, service to taxpayers; or by reducing taxpayer burden. c. Advocacy Project -- An advocacy issue that has been reviewed, under established criteria, and accepted as a project for assignment further development. d. Advocacy Proposal -- A formal, written memorandum of a recom- mended change that is presented to an Operating Division (OD) or function empowered to implement the change.
Program Effectiveness: SP and BOE are used to help identify open inventory and project progression, and issues being addressed.
BOE is a data analysis system. Reports are created and accessed by limited personnel. Reports can only be deleted by a designated administrator.

While SA generally takes the lead in resolving systemic problems, SA often partners with a variety of offices within TAS, the IRS, and external (to IRS)
SA also collaborates with various IRS offices to ensure actions they agreed to take to address administrative recommendations made in the ARC are taken.

Advice about tax matters. Clearance Reviews

The IMD clearance reviews ensure changes in IRS policy, authority, and procedures do not cause unnecessary burden on taxpayers or violate taxpayers rights. TAS must clear IMDs before the IRS publishes an IRM that may affect taxpayers rights. TAS does the vast majority of IMD reviews during the normal clearance process.
Representation in examination, appeals, collection disputes, or tax tion; Advocacy in responding to IRS notices or correcting tax account problems; and Advice about tax matters.
Systemic (

) Outside of Clearance Process (OCP) Review - In resolving systemic SA may identify needed IMD changes. An OCP recommendation identiﬁes requests a needed change to an IMD outside of the normal review (
) For more details on the IMD/SPOC program, see IRM
, TAS Management Document (IMD) Program. (

) Systemic Advocacy has three types of Information Gathering Projects • Monitor IGP identiﬁes emerging trends or issues generated from Gathering legislation or signiﬁcant IRS policy, process, or procedural changes looks for potential systemic issues; • Research IGP identiﬁes issues that may be systemic but SA needs conduct more research into the problem than the issue review allows; • IMD/SPOC IGP identiﬁes issues with changes that improve a protect taxpayer rights or reduce taxpayer burden to IRMs, forms, cation, letters, etc. (
) SA may reclassify an IGP as an advocacy project, immediate intervention other ongoing advocacy effort if the research indicates additional action be taken to resolve the issue. (
) Advocacy Projects are created to: • Identify and address systemic and procedural issues; Projects • Analyze the underlying causes of problems; and • Propose corrective action. (

) Intermediate Interventions are created to address issues that arise in circumstances: Interventions • Result from an operational issue that causes immediate, signiﬁcant harm to multiple taxpayers and demands an urgent response; • Cannot be quickly resolved through the normal corrective process; • Have clear sources of the problems; and • Are highly visible and sensitive locally, area-wide, or nationally. (

) Although advocacy projects are similar to immediate interventions, the of an advocacy project issue does not require immediate action by SA. Advocacy projects may require more extensive research and negotiation the IRS than an immediate intervention. (

) An advocacy proposal is a formal, written memorandum of a change presented to the IRS process owner empowered to implement the Proposal change. When the IRS is slow or reluctant to embrace the concerns raised SA, SA may consider an advocacy proposal. For a detailed discussion of and how to issue an advocacy proposal see IRM
, SAMS (
) If the IRS still does not agree, the EDSA may ask the NTA to consider a TRIS or a TAD.

) Membership on cross-functional teams, task forces, advocacy issue and councils provide SA with an opportunity to make administrative Efforts recommendations to existing processes. These memberships can also and avoid potential harm to taxpayers in proposed IRS processes. (
) SA assists the NTA in the preparation of: • ARC NTA • TRISs; • TADs; and • Other work as assigned. (
) IRC §

)(B) requires the NTA to submit two reports each year to Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives and the to Committee on Finance of the Senate. These reports are: • The NTA’s Fiscal Year Objectives Report to Congress (JRC); and • The NTA’s ARC. (

) The NTA can elevate systemic issues and make recommendations for tion through inclusion in the ARC. In instances where resolution of a issue involves a legislative change, the NTA can include a legislative mendation in the ARC. SA plays a signiﬁcant role in developing the ARC assisting in the identiﬁcation of the
most serious problems, as well as assisting in identifying topics for other parts of the report. (
) For more information about the NTA’s Annual Reports to Congress, see
NTA ARC. (

The NTA can elevate systemic issues and make recommendations for resolu- tion through inclusion in the ARC. In instances where resolution of a systemic issue involves a legislative change, the NTA can include a legislative recom- mendation in the ARC. SA plays a signiﬁcant role in developing the ARC by assisting in the identiﬁcation of the 10 most serious problems, as well as assisting in identifying topics for other parts of the report.

A TRIS is a written analysis from the NTA to the IRS process owner of action that infringes on taxpayers’ rights or unnecessarily burdens taxpayers. TAS will generally not send a TRIS until after the IRS is given an opportunity to work with the NTA to resolve the issue. See IRM 13.2.2 for additional information on how SA assists the NTA with TRISs.
